metadata.case_name: Various Beedi Manufacturers and Trade Mark Holders v. Union of India and States
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 1553, 1614-1618, 1769 of 1971 and others

facts.text: The beedi industry is widespread in India, manufacture done in stages: blending tobacco, putting on beedi leaf, rolling, closing ends, collecting, warming/roasting, packing, labelling.

Three systems in beedi manufacture: (1) factory system with direct employees; (2) contract system where proprietor gives materials to middlemen/contractors who employ labourers or distribute to home workers; (3) outworkers rolling beedis directly for proprietor.

Contractors engage less than 20 workers to evade Factories Act; fragmentation to avoid factory legislation; no master-servant relation sometimes; branch managers men of straw; exploitation of illiterate women and child labour.
Royal Commission on Labour 1931: beedi making in small airless workshops, unregulated hours, no holidays, piece rate payment.
Rege Committee 1944: contract system, unhealthy conditions, long hours, child/women employment, sub-contract system.
Madras Court of Inquiry 1946: 90,000 workers, 26,500 women, 2/5 children, home workers predominant, poor conditions.
Natraj Report 1954: only 17,544 in factories out of 1 lakh workers; contract/home system exploits workers, evasion of laws.
Petitioners/appellants: proprietors of beedi factories, trade mark holders, some home workers; challenged Act as unconstitutional.
Appeals from judgments of Mysore HC (24 June 1971), Madras HC (8 Sept 1972), Bombay HC, Gujarat HC, Andhra Pradesh HC.

Mysore HC upheld ss 3,4,26,27,31; Madras HC struck down ss 7(1)(c),7(2),26,27,31,37(3) for home workers; Bombay HC invalidated definitions in ss 2(g)(a),(b),2(m), ss 26,27 for home workers; Kerala HC struck down several ss; AP HC struck ss 3,4, held inapplicable to home workers.

legal_issues.text: Whether Parliament has legislative competence to enact the Beedi and Cigar Workers (Conditions of Employment) Act, 1966.
Whether the Act violates Article 19(1)(g) by imposing unreasonable restrictions on trade/business, particularly vicarious liability on principal employers for contract/home workers.
Whether sections 3 and 4 (licensing) are arbitrary/unconstitutional violating Arts 14,19(1)(g).
Whether sections 7(1)(c),26,27,31,37(3) (leave, notice, maternity) are unconstitutional/unenforceable for home workers.
Whether definitions in ss 2(e),(f),(g),(m) create fictional employer-employee relation imposing unreasonable burdens.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act falls under Entry 24 List II (industries), Parliament lacks competence; not labour welfare under List III.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entries 24 List II, 7/52 List I, 22-24 List III

petitioner_arguments.text: Imposes vicarious liability on manufacturers/trade mark holders for independent contractors/home workers over whom no control; no master-servant relation.
Ss 3,4 confer unfettered discretion on licensing authority without safeguards.
Ss 26,27 (leave with wages) unworkable for home workers: irregular hours, no full-time earnings calculable; no min days required.
Ss 7(1)(c),31,37(3) unreasonable for home workers: entry, notice, maternity inapplicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Act is labour welfare legislation under Entries 22-24 List III; regulates conditions of work in beedi industry.
Definitions recognize contract/home workers; principal employer liable as labour engaged for/on their behalf; prevents evasion.
Ss 3,4 have guidelines, appeal safeguard; not arbitrary.
Ss 26,27 applicable to home workers via definitions; wages calculable on piece rate/records; reasonable welfare measure.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss 2(f),(h), 26,27 Expl.II; Mysore Rules Forms XIII,XIV

court_reasoning.text: Act valid under Entries 22-24 List III as labour welfare/conditions of work; not industry regulation under List II.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pith and substance is regulation of conditions of employment in beedi/cigar industry.

court_reasoning.text: Ss 3,4 not arbitrary: objective criteria in s4, reasons for refusal, appeal to s5.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Safeguards prevent abuse; applies to industrial premises.

court_reasoning.text: Definitions ss 2(e),(f),(g),(m) valid; principal employer liable for contract labour engaged for/on their behalf; no vicarious liability for independent contractors (who become principal employers themselves).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prevents evasion via straw men; control via registers/log books.

court_reasoning.text: Ss 26,27 apply to home workers (employees in establishments); wages on daily average full time earnings (piece rate basis, records); workable via rules/forms; reasonable restriction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Home worker day=any employment period in 24 hrs; impetus to work more.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes prior cases: home workers under control via materials/rejection; entitled to benefits.
Alagiriswami J (separate): Ss 26,27,31,37(3) do not apply to home workers; definitions rope in everyone causing difficulties; Act needs amendment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Good intentions should not lead to ineffective legislation/litigation.

holdings.text: Beedi Act, 1966 constitutionally valid; Parliament competent.
Ss 2(g)(a),(b), 2(m), 3,4 valid; no unreasonable restriction under Art 19(1)(g).
Ss 26,27 applicable/enforceable for home workers and industrial premises workers.

statutes_cited.name: Beedi and Cigar Workers (Conditions of Employment) Act, 1966
statutes_cited.relevance: Core Act challenged; definitions, licensing, leave, maternity, etc. upheld as welfare measures

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinguished; evasion via <20 workers; safety provisions applied via s38

outcome.summary: Supreme Court (Ray CJ for majority) upheld constitutional validity of the Beedi and Cigar Workers Act, 1966, definitions, ss 3,4,26,27 etc.; applicable to home workers; appeals/petitions dismissed. Alagiriswami J agreed on most but held ss 26,27,31,37(3) inapplicable to home workers.

key_quotes.text: The pith and substance of this Act is regulation of conditions of employment in the beedi and cigar industry.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines legislative competence under List III

key_quotes.text: The manufacturer or trade mark holder becomes the principal employer though he engages contract labour through the contractor.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Sections 26 and 27 of the Act are to be read together... home workers are entitled to wages during the leave period.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It has to be held... that sections 26, 27, 31 and 37(3) do not apply to the home workers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Alagiriswami J's separate opinion limiting provisions
